name: Threat Actor Profiling
description: Analyzing cybercriminal groups, APTs, and state-sponsored hacking operations.

cards.title: Tracking Advanced Persistent Threats (APTs)
cards.description: Identifying and monitoring nation-state and corporate-sponsored hacking groups.
bulletpoints: Use MITRE ATT&CK to map APT tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs)
Analyze samples from VirusTotal, Hybrid Analysis, and Any.Run for malware attribution
Monitor geopolitical events and threat intelligence reports from Recorded Future, CrowdStrike, and Mandiant

cards.title: Cybercriminal Network Analysis
cards.description: Profiling cybercrime syndicates and underground hacking forums.
bulletpoints: Monitor dark web marketplaces with tools like DarkOwl, CipherTrace, and Tor search engines
Analyze ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) operations using MalwareBazaar and Malpedia
Track cryptocurrency laundering via blockchain analysis tools like Chainalysis and Elliptic

cards.title: Command & Control (C2) Infrastructure Tracking
cards.description: Identifying and disrupting malware command-and-control (C2) servers.
bulletpoints: Use PassiveDNS services like RiskIQ and VirusTotal for domain tracking
Analyze C2 beaconing behavior with Suricata, Zeek (Bro), and Wireshark
Cross-reference IP addresses with Shodan, Censys, and GreyNoise

cards.title: Social Engineering & Human Intelligence (HUMINT)
cards.description: Understanding how threat actors use deception and manipulation in cyber operations.
bulletpoints: Analyze phishing campaigns using PhishTank and OpenPhish
Use OSINT (Open-Source Intelligence) tools like SpiderFoot and Maltego to investigate fake identities
Monitor underground forums and Telegram channels for recruitment tactics

cards.title: Attributing Malware to Threat Actors
cards.description: Identifying malware families and their associated hacking groups.
bulletpoints: Use YARA rules to detect known malware signatures
Analyze malware samples with IDA Pro, Ghidra, and Remnux
Map findings to publicly known threats in MITRE ATT&CK and MISP Threat Sharing Platform

cards.title: Dark Web Threat Actor Monitoring
cards.description: Tracking cybercriminals and intelligence leaks on the dark web.
bulletpoints: Use Tor and I2P networks to monitor cybercriminal activities
Analyze forum discussions and marketplace listings with DarkOwl and Flashpoint
Use breach monitoring tools like Have I Been Pwned (HIBP) to track leaked credentials

cards.title: Insider Threat Actor Profiling
cards.description: Identifying internal risks from employees and compromised insiders.
bulletpoints: Use User and Entity Behavior Analytics (UEBA) with Splunk and Exabeam
Monitor abnormal file access and privilege escalation
Track corporate leaks on paste sites and anonymous platforms like Dread and 4chan

cards.title: Zero-Day Exploit Attribution
cards.description: Tracking zero-day vulnerabilities and identifying actors exploiting them.
bulletpoints: Monitor CVE (Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures) disclosures using Vulners and ExploitDB
Analyze zero-day exploit sales in underground markets
Use honeypots to detect exploitation attempts in real time

cards.title: Threat Actor Profiling via Social Media
cards.description: Tracking and analyzing cyber threat actors on social media platforms.
bulletpoints: Monitor APT-linked Twitter accounts using OSINT tools like Twint
Use Facebook and LinkedIn analysis to map threat actor affiliations
Analyze Discord, Telegram, and WhatsApp groups for recruitment and coordination activity

cards.title: Avoiding Attribution Pitfalls & False Flags
cards.description: Understanding the challenges of accurate threat actor attribution.
bulletpoints: Recognize false flag operations designed to mislead investigators
Cross-reference attack methods, infrastructure, and TTPs for reliability
Use a combination of SIGINT, HUMINT, and OSINT for multi-source verification
